revision.text:
{{Expand list|date=October 2017}}
{{More citations needed|list|date=January 2009}} The following is a list of '''people who were beheaded''', arranged alphabetically by country or region and with date of [[decapitation]]. Special sections on "Religious figures" and "Fictional characters" are also appended.
These individuals may have lost their heads either accidentally or intentionally (as a form of execution or posthumously).
[[File:Vecelli, Tiziano - Judith - c. 1515.jpg|thumb|''[[Salome (opera)|Salome]] and the Beheading of [[John the Baptist|St. John the Baptist]]'', by [[Titian]]]]
[[File:Decapitación de San Pablo - Simonet - 1887.jpg|right|thumb|''The Beheading of [[Saint Paul]]''. Painting by [[Enrique Simonet]] in 1887]]
==Argentina== * Oscar Lofeudo (1998) - Decapitated in a TC2000 pre-race qualifying in [[Rafaela, Argentina|Rafaela]] circuit; Lofeudo was then co-driver along with [[Raúl Petrich]] (driver who also died). * Daniel Ponce (2001) - Decapitated in a pick-up racing race, in [[San Martín, Mendoza]]. * Matías Viapiano (2003)- Decapitated in a karting race in [[Estación Aráoz, Tucumán]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lagaceta.com.ar/nota/54476/deportes/piloto-murio-terrible-accidente.html|title=A Driver Dies in a Terrible Accident. Drama in Estación Aráoz.|last=|first=|date=|website=La Gaceta|access-date=}}</ref>
==Australia==
*[[List of fatal shark attacks in Australia|Shirley Ann Durdin]] (1985) – Durdin was decapitated by a [[great white shark]] while snorkeling in [[South Australia]]; she was eaten alive<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tomorrowoman.com/leisure/horrifying-shark-attacks-history/4/|title=Most Horrifying Shark Attacks in History - TomorroWoman|date=6 November 2016|publisher=|accessdate=25 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/southafrica/6984067/Worlds-10-worst-shark-attacks.html|title=World's 10 worst shark attacks|publisher=|accessdate=25 February 2017}}</ref> *Kerry McLoughlin (1987) - Decapitated by a [[saltwater crocodile]] at Cahills Crossing in the [[Northern Territory]]<ref>http://www.ntnews.com.au/news/northern-territory/fishing-community-in-shock-after-man-snatched-from-boat-while-fishing-in-kakadu/news-story/dbfa77b73dd3ba0a190b4a31cce23a33?nk=49c4cd23d9cade7484a2f7bf8d0c58ca-1511369312</ref>
==Austria== *[[Joseph Haydn]] (1809) – celebrated composer posthumously beheaded; see [[Haydn's head]]
==Brazil== *[[Death of Otávio Jordão da Silva|Jordão da Silva Cantanhede]] (2013) – a Brazilian amateur [[association football|football]] referee,<ref name="NY News">{{cite web | url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/fans-decapitate-soccer-referee-brazil-police-article-1.1391892 | title=Fans decapitate soccer referee after he stabs, kills player:police | publisher=NY Daily News | date=6 July 2013 | accessdate=7 July 2013}}</ref> was [[lynching|lynched]], quartered and beheaded by football spectators after he stabbed a player in a match he officiated on June 30, 2013. Spectators then put his head on a stake in the middle of the pitch. A viral video later surfaced of medical officials reassembling his body.<ref name="BBC">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-23215676 | title=Brazil referee decapitated after stabbing player | work=BBC News | date=7 July 2013 | accessdate=7 July 2013}}</ref><ref name="IBT">{{cite web | url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/487093/20130706/otavio-jordao-da-silva-brazil-football-referee.htm | title=Brazilian Referee Beheaded by Fans for Killing Player | publisher=International Business Times | date=6 July 2013 | accessdate=7 July 2013}}</ref><ref name="Deadspin">{{cite web | url=http://deadspin.com/referee-kills-player-then-gets-beheaded-at-brazilian-so-685459212 | title=Brazilian Soccer Fans Decapitate Ref After He Stabs, Kills Player | publisher=Deadspin | date=6 July 2013 | accessdate=7 July 2013}}</ref> *[[João Rodrigo Silva Santos]] (2013) – Brazilian football player
==Byzantine Empire== * [[Phocas]] (610) - Emperor overthrown and beheaded by [[Heraclius]]
==Canada== *[[Murder of Tim McLean|Tim McLean]] (2008) – murdered and decapitated on Greyhound bus *Fribjon Bjornson (2012) – severed head found on the Nak'azdli reserve near Fort St. James<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/northern-b-c-homicide-witnesses-silenced-by-gang-fears-1.1202737|title= Northern B.C. homicide witnesses silenced by gang fears|accessdate = 11 October 2013}}</ref>
==China== [[Image: Jingkeciqinwang.png|thumb|250px|right|Mural depicting [[Jing Ke]]'s assassination attempt on the [[Qin Shi Huang|King of Qin]]; the severed head of Huan Yi is in an open box at bottom.]] *[[Huan Yi|Huan Yi (Fan Wuji)]] (桓齮, 227 BC) — Traitorous [[Qin (state)|Qin]] general; his severed head was instrumental in [[Jing Ke]]'s assassination attempt of the Qin king *[[Han Xin]] (韓信, 196 BC) – Executed by [[Empress Lü]] *[[Guan Yu]] (關羽, 219) – Executed during civil war by [[Sun Quan]] *[[Guan Ping]] (關平, 219) – son of Guan Yu, executed during civil war by [[Sun Quan]] *[[Wen Tianxiang]] (文天祥, 1283) – scholar and general *[[Francis Ferdinand de Capillas|St Francis de Capillas]](圣刘方济, 1648) – Beheaded at Fogan, China *[[Adolf Schlagintweit]] (1857) – German botanist and explorer; executed by the ruler of [[Kashgar]] *[[Tan Sitong]] (譚嗣同, 1898) – Executed with five others by [[Empress Dowager Cixi]]
==Chile== *[[José Larenas]] (1980) – Decapitated by a great white shark.<ref>http://sharkattackfile.net/spreadsheets/pdf_directory/1980.01.05-Miranda.pdf</ref> *[[Murder of María José Reyes and Juan Duarte|María José Reyes and Juan Duarte]] (2012) – Beheaded by a seller of antiquities in [[Lolol]]
==Democratic Republic of the Congo== *[[Zaida Catalán]] (2017) - Swedish politician of Chilean descent, found decapitated during 2017
==Denmark== *[[Anne Palles]] (1693) – Executed in Copenhagen for witchcraft *[[Johann Friedrich Struensee]] (1772) – Executed in Copenhagen for [[lèse-majesté]] *[[Enevold Brandt]] (1772) – Executed in Copenhagen for [[lèse-majesté]]

Giovanni Giacomo Sinibaldi | place of consecration = Saint Peter's Basilica, Rome, Papal States |elevated by = Pope Gregory XVI |date of elevation = {{unbulleted list|14 December 1840 (in pectore)|21 April 1845 (announced)}} |bishop 1 = Juraj Haulík Váralyai |consecration date 1 = 10 December 1837 |bishop 2 = Luigi Guglielmi |consecration date 2 = 10 May 1840 |bishop 3 = Gregorio Fistilli |consecration date 3 = 7 December 1845 |bishop 4 = [[Giovanni Corti]] |consecration date 4 = 25 April 1847 |bishop 5 = Francesco Emilio Cugini |consecration date 5 = 28 March 1852 |bishop 6 = [[Gaetano Bedini]] |consecration date 6 = 4 July 1852 |bishop 7 = Giuseppe Cardoni |consecration date 7 = 7 November 1852 |bishop 8 = Giovanni Francesco Magnani |consecration date 8 = 14 October 1855 |bishop 9 = Nicola Pace |consecration date 9 = 14 October 1855 |bishop 10 = Pietro Maria Ferrè |consecration date 10 = 29 March 1857 |bishop 11 = José Ignacio Checa y Barba |consecration date 11 = 29 December 1861 |bishop 12 = [[Luigi Oreglia di Santo Stefano]] |consecration date 12 = 13 May 1866 |bishop 13 = Antonio Rossi Vaccari |consecration date 13 = 1 June 1866 |bishop 14 = Antonius Grech-Delicata-Testaferrata |consecration date 14 = 14 July 1867 }} '''Lodovico Altieri''' (17 July 1805 – 11 August 1867) was an [[Italian people|Italian]] [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|cardinal]].{{citeweb|url=http://www2.fiu.edu/~mirandas/bios1840.htm|title=Consistory of December 14, 1840 (XVI)|author=Salvador Miranda|date=|publisher=The Cardinals of the Holy Roman Church|accessdate=1 December 2017}} He served in various capacities under various popes and belonged to a [[Altieri family|noble Roman house]] making him a descendant of [[Pope Clement X]]. The sainthood process commenced under [[Pope Benedict XVI]] and the late cardinal has been titled as a [[Servant of God]]. ==Life== Lodovico Altieri was born in [[Rome]] in 1805 as the last of three children to Paluzzo Altieri (21.07.1760-10.01.1834) and Maria Anna von Sachsen (20.10.1770-24.12.1845). His two older siblings were Clemente (06.08.1795-21.06.1873) and Augusto (1797-1860) who became a [[Jesuit]]. His father served from 1801 until his death as the commander for the [[Noble Guard (Vatican)|Papal Noble Guard]] after [[Pope Pius VII]] named him to that position. His brother Clemente succeeded their father in that role. He was [[baptized]] in the parish of San Marco mere moments after his birth. He was [[ordained]] to the [[priesthood]] in Rome on 24 March 1833. He was named after his ordination as the qualificator for the [[Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith|Congregation of the Inquisition]] while he served as the vicar for the [[Santa Maria in Via Lata]] school. During this time he also served as the aide for the [[Congregation for Catholic Education|Congregation of Studies]]. His rise through the ranks continued after he was appointed as the [[Catholic archdiocese of Ephesus|Titular Archbishop of Ephesus]]; he received his [[episcopal consecration]] from the pope himself in [[Saint Peter's Basilica]]. The [[co-consecrators]] were [[Giovanni Soglia Ceroni]] and Giovanni Giacomo Sinibaldi. He was also appointed as the [[apostolic nuncio]] to [[Habsburg Monarchy|Austria]] just after his consecration. His aide in the nunciature was the future cardinal [[Gaetano Bedini]]. It was he who encouraged Bedini to expose himself to the Church's diplomatic atmosphere. The pope created him as a cardinal but reserved him [[in pectore]] on 14 December 1840. His name was not announced until 21 April 1845 and he was made the [[Santa Maria in Campitelli|Cardinal-Priest of Santa Maria in Campitelli]] (the diaconate was elevated [[pro hac vice]] to a titular rank). He participated in the [[Papal conclave, 1846|conclave in 1846]] that elected [[Pope Pius IX]]. In that conclave he supported the candidature of Cardinal Mastai-Ferretti which formed a knit group among cardinals such as [[Clarissimo Falconieri Mellini]] and [[Luigi Amat di San Filippo e Sorso]].{{citebook|first=George|last=Fitz-Hardinge Berkeley|title=Italy in the Making: 1815 to 1846|date=1932|publisher=Cambridge University Press|accessdate=1 December 2017}} He was a member of the [[triumvirate]] that governed Rome between 1849 and 1850 after the short-lived [[Roman Republic (19th century)|Roman Republic]] together with cardinals Luigi Vannicelli Casoni and [[Gabriele della Genga Sermattei|Gabriele Sermattei della Genga]]. The disorder in 1848 saw Altieri flee with Pius IX to [[Gaeta]]. Pius IX held Altieri in great esteem and Altieri proved himself the center of opposition within the cardinalate to [[Giacomo Antonelli]]. He was the aide for the Congregation for Memorials from 1855 to 1857 and was later appointed [[Camerlengo of the Holy Roman Church]] on 19 March 1857; the cardinal held that position until his death. He later opted for the order of [[Cardinal-Bishop|Cardinal-Bishops]] and assumed the [[suburbicarian see]] of [[Suburbicarian See of Albano|Albano]] on 17 December 1860. He was later appointed as the [[Congregation of the Index|Prefect of the Congregation of the Index]] on 5 September 1861 and then appointed as the [[Archpriest|archpriest]] for the [[Basilica of Saint John Lateran]] on 8 March 1863. Altieri had little interactions with [[John Bosco|Saint Giovanni Bosco]] and once sent him in 1867 funds for Bosco's apostolic work in [[Turin]]. During the [[cholera]] epidemic that affected his suburbicarian see he assisted and tended to the ill though contracted it himself and died of it later on 11 August 1867. His funeral took place in [[Santa Maria in Campitelli]] and his remains were interred in [[Campo Verano]] before being transferred. ==Beatification process== The beatification process commenced under [[Pope Benedict XVI]] once the [[Congregation for the Causes of Saints]] issued the official "[[nihil obstat]]" (no objections) and titled him as a [[Servant of God]] on 14 March 2009. The diocesan process of the investigation was inaugurated in Albano on 22 November 2009 and concluded its investigations later on 26 September 2015. The current [[postulator]] for this cause is Dr. Ulderico Parente. ==See also== *[[Altieri family]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://newsaints.faithweb.com/year/1867.htm#Altieri {{short description|3rd-century BC Roman consul}} {{Infobox Politician | name = Lucius Aemilius Papus | image = | caption = | birth_date = Unknown | birth_place = | residence = | death_date = Unknown | death_place = | office = [[List of Roman Republican consuls|Consul]] of the [[Roman Republic]] | term_start = January 225 BC | term_end = June 225 BC | alongside = [[Gaius Atilius Regulus (consul 225 BC)|Gaius Atilius Regulus]] | predecessor = [[Marcus Valerius Messalla (consul 226 BC)|Marcus Valerius Messalla]] and [[Lucius Apustius Fullo]] | successor = [[Titus Manlius Torquatus (235 BC)|Titus Manlius Torquatus]] and [[Quintus Fulvius Flaccus]] | constituency = | party = | occupation = | spouse = | children = | footnotes = | nickname = | allegiance =[[Roman Empire]] | branch = | serviceyears = | rank = | commands = | battles = [[Battle of Telamon]] }} '''Lucius Aemilius Papus''' ([[floruit|fl.]] 216 BC) was a Roman general and statesman. He jointly commanded the Roman armies which defeated the [[Gaul]]s at the [[Battle of Telamon]] in 225 BC; his co-Consul, [[Gaius Atilius Regulus (consul 225 BC)|Gaius Atilius Regulus]] was killed during the battle. Papus was honoured with a [[roman triumph|triumph]] for this victory. He subsequently held several senior positions. He belonged to the [[Patrician (ancient Rome)|patrician]] ''[[gens]] [[Aemilia (gens)|Aemilia]]''. == Ancestry == William Smith says that Papus was the grandson of [[Quintus Aemilius Papus]], himself the grandson of (a different) Quintus Aemilius Papus. His grandfather had been [[Roman consul|consul]] twice and [[Roman censor|censor]] once.William Smith. (1870). [http://www.ancientlibrary.com/smith-bio/2453.html "Papus - Q. Aemilius Papus"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514091238/http://www.ancientlibrary.com/smith-bio/2453.html |date=May 14, 2011 }} == Career == [[File:Talamone - Vista dalla giannella.JPG|thumb|The hills around the site of the [[Battle of Telamon]]]] Papus was consul for 225, with [[Gaius Atilius Regulus (consul 225 BC)|Gaius Atilius Regulus]] as his colleague. That year the [[Boii]], [[Insubres]] and [[Taurisci]] of [[Cisalpine Gaul]] enlisted the aid of the mercenary [[Gaesatae]] and mobilised against Rome. Papus was stationed at Ariminum (modern [[Rimini, Italy|Rimini]]) to guard against them. Regulus' army was at this time stationed in [[Sardinia]]. A smaller force of Roman allies was stationed on the border of [[Etruria]] under a [[praetor]], and it was this force that encountered the Gauls first, suffering a defeat at [[Battle of Faesulae|Faesulae]] (modern [[Fiesole]]). Papus arrived shortly after the battle and this persuaded the Gauls to withdraw along the coast.{{sfn|Goldworthy|2000|p=139}} Meanwhile, Regulus had crossed from Sardinia, landed at Pisa, and was marching towards Rome. His scouts met the Celts' advance guard head-on near Telamon (modern Talamone), in an area called Campo Regio, to the surprise of both. As soon as they realised that they faced a second full Roman army they deployed their infantry facing both front and rear, with their flanks protected by wagons and chariots. The [[Battle of Telamon|fighting was fierce]], with Regulus being killed early in the battle and his head brought to the Celtic leaders. Eventually, the surrounded Gauls were worn down and broke. Most of their cavalry fled, but forty thousand Gauls are reported to have died with ten thousand being taken prisoner.{{sfn|Mommsen|2015|p=689}} The Romans lost six thousand killed and many more wounded.{{sfn|Perrett|1992|p=289}} After the battle Papus marched the army into [[Liguria]] and the territory of the [[Boii]] to conduct punitive actions. The defeat of the Gauls was so heavy that they never threatened Rome again. Papus was awarded the honour of a [[Roman triumph|triumph]].{{sfn|Goldworthy|2000|p=139}}[[Polybius]], [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Polybius/2*.html#21 'The Histories of Polybius'], Book 2. pp. 21–31. Papus was censor in 220, with [[Gaius Flaminius]] as his colleague.[[Livy]]. (1905). ''From the Founding of the City'', [[s:From the Founding of the City/Book 23#23|Book 23.23]] In 218 he was one of five men sent as an embassy to [[Carthage]] following [[Hannibal]]'s [[siege of Saguntum]]. The embassy was sent to obtain satisfaction for the capture and destruction of the city, which had been under Rome's protection. The mission ended with the Roman delegation declaring war on the floor of the Carthaginian senate and so starting the [[Second Punic War]].{{sfn|Goldworthy|2000|p=145}}[[Livy]]. (1905). ''From the Founding of the City'', [[s:From the Founding of the City/Book 21#18|Book 21.18]] In 216 Papus was one of the ''[[triumviri]]'' appointed to deal with Rome's lack of money during the war.[[Livy]]. (1905). ''From the Founding of the City'', [[s:From the Founding of the City/Book 23#21|Book 23.21]] == Death == There are no surviving records of when Papus died, nor of whether he left any surviving children. == References == {{reflist}} == Sources == * {{cite book|last=Goldworthy|first=Adrian|title=The Fall of Carthage|date=2000|location=London|publisher=Phoenix|ISBN=9780304366422|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last=Mommsen|first=T.|title=History of Rome, Vol. I|location=London|publisher=Forgotten Books|date=2015|isbn=9781440043581|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last=Perrett|first=Bryan|title=The Battle Book|publisher=Arms and Armour Press|location=London|date=1992|isbn=1860198473|ref=harv}} {{s-start}} {{succession box|title=[[List of Roman Republican consuls|Consul]] of the [[Roman Republic]]|before=[[Marcus Valerius Messalla (consul 226 BC)|Marcus Valerius Messalla]] and [[Lucius Apustius Fullo]]||after=[[Titus Manlius Torquatus (235 BC)|Titus Manlius Torquatus]] and [[Quintus Fulvius Flaccus]]|years=''with [[Gaius Atilius Regulus (consul 225 BC)|Gaius Atilius Regulus]]''
225 BC}} {{s-end}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aemilius Papus, Lucius}} [[Category:Roman Republican consuls]] [[Category:Roman censors]] [[Category:Aemilii|Papus, Lucius]] [[Category:3rd-century BC Romans]] [[Category:3rd-century BC births]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]]

{{small|(Withdrawn)}} | military_blank1 = | military_data1 = | military_blank2 = | military_data2 = | military_blank3 = | military_data3 = | military_blank4 = | military_data4 = | military_blank5 = | military_data5 = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | footnotes = }} '''Mansurul Haq''' ([[Urdu]]: منصور الحق; October 16 1931{{cite web |last1=Pakistan |first1=Tareekh e |title=پاک بحریہ کے سربراہ۔ ایڈمرل منصور الحق|url=http://www.tareekhepakistan.com/detail?title_id=2208&dtd_id=2089 |website=www.tareekhepakistan.com |accessdate=25 July 2018}}–February 21 2018) was a former [[Four-star admiral|four-star]] rank [[admiral]] in the [[Pakistan Navy]] who was forcibly retired from his [[Commissioned officer|commission]] in 1997 on the allegations leveled against him in the [[Karachi affair|corruption and kickbacks]] resulting during the [[technology transfer]] of submarines from [[France]]. Driving a policy on anti-corruption by the [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] [[Nawaz Sharif]], the [[Naval Intelligence (Pakistan)|Naval Intelligence]] led by [[Rear-Admiral]] [[Tanvir Ahmad (admiral)|Tanvir Ahmad]] exposed his role that led to his resignation on 1 May 1997. His case attracted subsequent media attention in Pakistan after his extradition from the [[United States]] by the joint teams of [[Federal Investigation Agency|FIA]] and [[National Accountability Bureau|NAB]], and was held in [[Prisons in Pakistan|Sihala Prison]] to face accountability.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/1274259.stm "Former Pakistani navy chief arrested"] ''BBC News'', 12 April 2001{{cite news|last1=Staff Writer|title=Ex-chief of Navy stripped of rank, benefits|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/17343|accessdate=21 August 2017|work=DAWN.COM|agency=Dawn Newspaper|publisher=Dawn Newspaper, 2002|date=31 January 2002|language=en}} However, Haq was later released after successfully negotiating a [[plea bargain]] and was released.[http://www.dawn.com/2002/07/17/local5.htm "Masoorul Haq held in another NAB reference"] ''Dawn'', 17 July 2002 In 2013, he later filed a lawsuit against the [[Government of Pakistan]] at the [[Sindh High Court]], seeking to restore his rank and other privileges, which the government restored his rank but not his privileges.{{cite news|last1=staff writer|title=SHC gives govt last chance to reply on Mansurul Haq's petition {{!}} Pakistan News Index|url=https://pakistannewsindex.com/shc-gives-govt-last-chance-to-reply-on-mansurul-haqs-petition/|accessdate=21 August 2017|work=pakistannewsindex.com|agency=pakistannewsindex|publisher=pakistannewsindex|date=12 October 2013}} ==Biography== Mansurul Haq was born in [[Sialkot]], [[Punjab, British India|Punjab]] in [[British Indian Empire|India]], in 1937 into a [[Punjabi people|Punjabi family]].{{cite web|last1=Pakistan|first1=Tareekh e|title=Admiral Mansur ul Haq (پاک بحریہ کے سربراہ۔ ایڈمرل منصور الحق)|url=http://www.tareekhepakistan.com/detail?title_id=2208&dtd_id=2089|website=www.tareekhepakistan.com|publisher=Tareekh e Pakistan (پاک بحریہ کے سربراہ۔ ایڈمرل منصور الحق))|accessdate=23 August 2017|language=ur|format=id|date=1994}} After his matriculation in Sialkot, he briefly attended the [[Murray College]] and [[Commissioned officer|commissioned]] in the [[Pakistan Navy]] in 1954 as [[Midshipman]]. In 1954, he was sent to the [[United Kingdom]] where he attended the [[Britannia Royal Naval College]] in [[Dartmouth, Devon|Dartmouth]] in [[England]], graduated in [[Maritime geography|geography]] course in 1956. In 1957, he did his further military training at the [[HMS Excellent (shore establishment)|HMS Excellent]] in [[Portsmouth]] where he specialized as [[Naval gunnery|gunnery specialist]], returned to [[Pakistan]] before being promoted as [[Sub lieutenant|Sub-Lieutenant]] in the Navy in 1958. In 1964–65, [[Lieutenant (naval)|Lt.]] Haq served in the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965|second war]] with India, and was posted in [[East Pakistan]] after the war. In 1969–71, [[Lieutenant-Commander]] Haq was posted with [[Pakistan Eastern Command|Eastern Command]] where he was the [[Director (business)|Director]] of the [[Naval Intelligence of Pakistan|Naval Intelligence]], fighting a war against [[India]] in December 1971.{{cite web|last1=Kazi|first1=Dr. AGN|title=Gen Abdul Hamid Khan meets Lt Cdr (later Admiral) Mansur ul Haq in East Pakistan, 1971|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/pimu/4244050697/|website=Flickr|publisher=AGN Kazis' file|accessdate=23 August 2017|language=en-us|date=1971}} He was taken as [[Pakistani prisoners of war in India|war prisoner]] by [[Indian Army]] and was repatriated back to Pakistan following the [[Delhi Agreement|trilateral agreement]] signed in 1974.{{cite news|last1=Tariq|first1=Kamala|title=KARACHI: Notice issued on Mansur’s petition|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/139826/karachi-notice-issued-on-mansur-s-petition|accessdate=23 August 2017|work=DAWN.COM|agency=Dawn newspapers|publisher=Dawn newspapers, 2005|date=19 May 2005|location=Karachi, Pakistan|language=en-pk}}{{rp|248–249}}{{cite book|last1=Sirohey|first1=Iftikhar Ahmed|title=Truth Never Retires: An Autobiography of Admiral Iftikhar Ahmed Sirohey|date=1995|publisher=Jang Publishers|location=Karachi, Sind, Pk|pages=592|edition=1st|language=en-pk}} His career progressed extremely well in the Navy, and was sent to attend the [[US Naval War College|Naval War College]] in [[Rhode Island]] in the [[United States]] where he graduated in management course. In 1983, [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] Haq was promoted to one-star assignment in the [[NHQ (Pakistan Navy)|Navy NHQ]], and [[Commodore (rank)|Cdre]] Haq briefly tenured as the [[Assistant Chief of the Naval Staff|ACNS (Ops)]].Economic Review, Volume 24, Page 94 - Economic & Industrial Publications., 1993 In 1985–89, [[Commodore (rank)|Cdre]] Haq served in the [[Ministry of Defence (Pakistan)|Ministry of Defence]] and later as Director of Joint Training at the [[Joint Staff Headquarters (Pakistan)|JS HQ]] before being promoted to two-star assignment, and [[Rear-Admiral]] Haq was made a senior [[Fleet Commander|fleet commander]] as Commander Pakistan Fleet (COMPAK), and later as Commander Karachi (COMKAR) in 1991–92.{{rp|337}}{{cite book|title=Pakistan Year Book|date=1992|publisher=East & West Publishing Company|url=https://books.google.com/?id=z8kEAQAAIAAJ&q=mansurul+haq+Commander+Karachi&dq=mansurul+haq+Commander+Karachi|accessdate=23 August 2017}} On 22 February 2018, his family's spokesperson reportedly announced in a [[Pakistani media|news media]] of his passing in his estate in [[Dubai]] and was buried in military graveyard in Karachi.{{cite news |title=Admiral (r) Mansurul Haq passes away at 81 |url=https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2018/02/22/admiral-r-mansurul-haq-passes-away-at-81/ |accessdate=30 July 2018 |work=www.pakistantoday.com.pk}} ==Chief of Naval Staff== {{Main|Karachi affair|l1=Agosta Submarines Scandal}} In 1992, [[Rear-Admiral]] Haq was promoted to [[Three-star rank|three-star]] assignment, and was appointed as [[secondment]] at the [[Pakistan National Shipping Corporation|National Shipping Corporation]] (PNSC) by then-[[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Naval Staff]] Admiral [[Saeed Mohammad Khan|S.M. Khan]]. However, his chairmanship was caught between the [[Privatization in Pakistan|privatization policy]] led by then-[[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] [[Nawaz Sharif]] and Admiral [[Saeed Mohammad Khan|S.M. Khan]], when a civilian bureaucrat filed a petition against his tenureship at the [[Sindh High Court]].{{rp|contents}}{{cite book|last1=Prasad|first1=Dr Nitin|title=Contemporary Pakistan: Political System, Military and Changing Scenario|date=2016|publisher=Vij Books India Pvt Ltd|isbn=9789385505270|url=https://books.google.com/?id=FLufCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT54&dq=mansurul+haq+vice+admiral#v=onepage&q=mansurul%20haq%20vice%20admiral&f=false|accessdate=23 August 2017|language=en}} [[Vice-Admiral]] Haq fiercely opposed any attempts of [[Privatization in Pakistan|privatization policy]], causing a stress on the [[civil-military relations]] with the [[Government of Pakistan|civilian federal government]].{{rp|contents}} In 1992, Vice-Admiral Haq announced to sell off the old metal scrap that would raise the revenue of [[United States Dollar|US$]]50–60 million to buy new [[cargo ship]]s.{{rp|4}}{{cite book|title=Lloyd's List Maritime Asia|date=1994|publisher=Lloyd's of London Press|url=https://books.google.com/?id=e7u1AAAAIAAJ&dq=mansurul+haq+vice+admiral&q=mansurul+haq|accessdate=23 August 2017|language=en}} In 1994, [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] [[Benazir Bhutto]] publicly announced to promote [[Vice-Admiral]] Haq as a [[four-star admiral]] in the Navy, appointing him as the [[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Naval Staff]].{{rp|35}} The promotion came with controversy since Vice-Admiral Mansur was due retirement a month before the change was due.{{rp|35}}{{cite book|last1=Anwar|first1=Muhammad|last2=Baig|first2=Ebad|title=Pakistan: Time for Change|date=2012|publisher=AuthorHouse|isbn=9781477250303|pages=160|url=https://books.google.com/?id=mb6OOYcrIOYC&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&dq=mansurul+haq++appointed+chief+Bhutto#v=onepage&q=mansurul%20haq%20%20appointed%20chief%20Bhutto&f=false|accessdate=23 August 2017|language=en|format=google books}} Although, it was Admiral [[Saeed Mohammad Khan]] who had given a go-ahead of procuring the [[technology transfer]] of the [[Agosta 90B class submarine|Agosta 90B submarines]] in 1994 against his discretionary and wanting to directly procure the [[Upholder/Victoria-class submarine|Victoria class]] submarines. Admiral Haq, nonetheless oversaw the financial deals closed in between the [[Bainazir Bhuttoo Government|Benazir administration]] and the administrations of [[François Mitterrand|Mitterrand]] and [[Jacques Chirac|Chirac]] in 1994–97.{{cite news|last1=Editorial|first1=et.al.|title=PPP govt, not Navy, purchased French subs, in a deal|url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/archive/print/617254-ppp-govt,-not-navy,-purchased-french-subs,-in-a-deal|accessdate=29 August 2017|work=www.thenews.com.pk|agency=News International|publisher=News International 2011|date=12 October 2011|location=Islamabad|language=en}} In 1995, Adm. Haq held additional talks with the [[French Navy]] over the strengthening of the cooperation between two nations.{{rp|56–60}}{{cite book|title=Daily Report: Near East & South Asia|date=1995|publisher=The Service|url=https://books.google.com/?id=oE2JA6uqTW8C&q=mansurul+haq+admiral&dq=mansurul+haq+admiral|accessdate=8 September 2017|language=en}} ==Dismissal and extradition== In 1996–97, the [[Naval Intelligence (Pakistan)|Naval Intelligence]] led by [[Rear-Admiral]] [[Tanvir Ahmed (admiral)|Tanvir Ahmed]] began investigating the allegations and rumors at the [[NHQ (Pakistan Navy)|Navy NHQ]] surrounding the role of Admiral [[Saeed Mohammad Khan|S.M. Khan]] and Admiral Haq.{{cite news|last1=Sharif|first1=Arshad|title=REPORTER-Kickbacks and commissions in Agosta submarine case-Part-3-Clip-1|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nW61REqvZrI|accessdate=29 August 2017|work=Dawn News|agency=Dawn News Network|publisher=Dawn News Network, 2010 P-I|date=30 December 2010|location=Islamabad|language=ur|format=watch.tv}} The whole nation became completely aware of the scandal in 1998, when the scandal was exposed. In driving the anti-corruption policy by then-[[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] [[Nawaz Sharif]], Admiral Haq's role was exposed by [[Rear-Admiral|R-Adm]] [[Tanvir Ahmed (admiral)|Tanvir Ahmed]], and was forced retired from his four-star commission in 1997.{{rp|90–91}}{{cite book|last1=Singh|first1=Ravi Shekhar Narain Singh|title=The Military Factor in Pakistan|date=2008|publisher=Lancer Publishers|isbn=9780981537894|url=https://books.google.com/?id=wCm2DFZblOYC&pg=PA90&dq=Mansurul+Haq#v=onepage&q=Mansurul%20Haq&f=false|accessdate=8 September 2017|language=en|format=google books|chapter=military and politics}}{{cite news|last1=Tohid|first1=Owais|title=Pakistan launches submarine|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/2213638.stm|accessdate=29 August 2017|work=news.bbc.co.uk|agency=BBC Pakistan Bureau|publisher=BBC Pakistan Bureau 2002|date=24 August 2002|location=Karachi, Pakistan|language=en-gp}} The [[Naval Police]] and officials of the [[Naval Intelligence (Pakistan)|Naval Intelligence]] led by R-Adm. [[Tanvir Ahmed (admiral)|Tanvir Ahmed]] arrested Admiral Haq but no evidence came out to convict him in 1998.{{cite news|last1=Sharif|first1=Arshad|title=REPORTER- Part-3-Clip-4|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k_MppEZD5LA|accessdate=29 August 2017|work=Dawn News|agency=Dawn News Network|publisher=Dawn News Network, 2010 P-III|date=30 December 2010|location=Karachi, Pakistan|language=ur|format=watch?v}}{{rp|contents}}{{cite book|last1=Sehri|first1=Inam|title=Judges and Generals in Pakistan|date=2013|publisher=Grosvenor House Publishing|isbn=9781781482346|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ZgRnAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT411&dq=mansurul+haq+navy+1998#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=29 August 2017|language=en}} In 1998, Haq [[Pakistani emigration to the United States|emigrated]] to the [[United States]] and settled in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] in [[Texas]] where he bought a house.{{cite web|last1=Ahmed, PN|first1=Rear Admiral Tanvir|title=CASE STUDY|url=http://www.nab.gov.pk/Downloads/Case_studies/mansoorulhaq.pdf|website=www.nab.gov.pk|publisher=NAB Press|accessdate=29 August 2017|location=Islamabad|language=en-pk|format=PDF|date=2001}} In 1999, the [[National Accountability Bureau]] (NAB) announced to open the investigations on [[Karachi affair|Agosta scandal]], with French [[Tracfin]] aiding the investigations, where major breakthrough in the investigation was made in 2000–01. In 2001, the [[Court system of Pakistan|anti-corruption courts]] issued the [[arrest warrants]], and [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Pervez Musharraf]] negotiated with the [[US President|U.S. President]] [[George W. Bush|George Bush]] for his extradition to Pakistan. The [[Texas Ranger Division|Texas Ranger]] detained him in Texas, and extradited him to Pakistan on 17 April 2001.{{rp|128}}{{cite book|last1=Sareen|first1=Tilak Raj|title=Socio-economic and Political Development in South Asia|date=2004|publisher=Gyan Publishing House|location=Delhi India|isbn=9788182050778|url=https://books.google.com/?id=SqON6vbskCAC&pg=PA128&dq=Mansurul+Haq+navy#v=onepage&q=Mansurul%20Haq%20navy&f=false|accessdate=8 September 2017|language=en}} While Haque had a right to fight for his extradition, he choose not to. ===Lawsuits, imprisonment and release=== In 2001, the [[Court system of Pakistan|Accountability Court]] inducted Haq in receiving commissions and kickbacks worth [[US Dollar|$]]3.369 million in defence deals.{{cite news|last1=Iqbal|first1=Nasir|title=ISLAMABAD: Former naval chief indicted in $3.369m kickbacks case|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/2814|accessdate=8 September 2017|work=DAWN.COM|agency=Dawn Newspaper|publisher=Dawn Newspaper, 2001|date=23 October 2001|language=en}} Civilian prosecution also leveled charges on him of being involved in financial deals made through selling the [[Metal scrap size reduction machine|metal scrap]] through the [[Pakistan National Shipping Corporation|National Shipping Corporation]] (PNSC), which caused the [[Pakistan National Shipping Corporation|PNSC]] to lose [[U.S. Dollar|$]]3 million in national exchequer. In 2004, the [[Court system of Pakistan|anti-corruption court]] sentenced him in rigorous seven-year rigorous imprisonment and fined [[Pakistan Rupee|₨.]]2 million.[http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/?page=story_20-3-2003_pg7_9 "SC directs NAB to hire new prosecutor for Mansur trial"] ''Daily Times'', 20 March 2003 Upon being convicted, the naval police shifted him in the [[Punjab Prisons (Pakistan)|Sihala Prison]] in [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]] in [[Pakistan]] but soon began his negotiation with the [[Government of Pakistan]] to return the money as [[plea bargain]] in exchange of light sentence and minimal jail time.{{cite news|last1=Staff writer|title=Ex-chief of Navy stripped of rank, benefits|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/17343|accessdate=8 September 2017|work=DAWN.COM|agency=Dawn Newspaper|publisher=Dawn Newspaper,2002|date=31 January 2002|language=en}} In 2003–05, Haq returned a total sum of [[US Dollar|$]]7.5 million while in office, which were immediately shifted back to Navy's national account.{{rp|71}}{{cite book|last1=Bureau|first1=Pakistan National Accountability|title=Annual Report|date=2002|publisher=National Accountability Bureau.|url=https://books.google.com/?id=p6-NAAAAMAAJ&q=admiral+Mansurul+Haq+7.5&dq=admiral+Mansurul+Haq+7.5|accessdate=8 September 2017|language=en}}{{rp|content}}{{cite book|last1=Lieven|first1=Anatol|title=Pakistan: A Hard Country|date=2012|publisher=PublicAffairs|isbn=9781610391627|url=https://books.google.com/?id=exBKSo-Pf6cC&pg=PT180&dq=Mansurul+Haq#v=onepage&q=Mansurul%20Haq&f=false|accessdate=8 September 2017|language=en}} The amount was said to be enough to pay the salaries of entire navy for two years.{{rp|213}}{{cite book|last1=Hill|first1=Geoff|title=The Battle for Zimbabwe: The Final Countdown|date=2003|publisher=Zebra|location=London, UK|isbn=9781868726523|pages=300|url=https://books.google.com/?id=wPqDEaeV2hQC&pg=PA213&dq=Mansurul+Haq+navy#v=onepage&q=Mansurul%20Haq%20navy&f=false|accessdate=8 September 2017|language=en-gb|format=google books|chapter=the money trail}} After transferring the amount back to Navy's account, Haq was released from the prison and all cases against him were closed as part of the deal, eventually settling in [[Karachi]].{{cite news|last1=Editorial|first1=et.al|title=Musharraf tried Haq under NAB law and Navy was not hurt|url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/archive/print/635483-musharraf-tried-haq-under-nab-law-and-navy-was-not-hurt|accessdate=8 September 2017|work=www.thenews.com.pk|agency=The News International|publisher=The News International, 2017|date=12 January 2014|language=en}} He paid additional [[US Dollar|US$]] 2.5 million which were deposited to Pakistan Navy's account in two easy installment payments, after which, he was released as the [[National Accountability Bureau|NAB agents]] vacated his house in Karachi.{{cite news|title=NAB agrees to free Admiral Mansur for Rs 457.5 million|url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/archive/print/340478-nab-agrees-to-free-admiral-mansur-for-rs-457.5-million|accessdate=8 September 2017|work=www.thenews.com.pk|date=2002|language=en}} In 2013, Haq filed a lawsuit against the [[Government of Pakistan]], seeking to restore his medical privileges, pensions, and four-star rank, at the [[Sindh High Court]]. Chief Justice of [[Sindh High Court]], Justice [[Faisal Arab]] (now serving as [[List of Justices of the Supreme Court of Pakistan|Justice]] in the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan]]), heard his appeal as Haq cited his 43 years of military service in the Navy who fought the [[Indo-Pakistani wars and conflicts|two wars]] where he was taken [[Pakistani prisoners of war in India|war prisoner]] by India in 1971. In 2013, the [[Government of Pakistan]] agreed to restore his rank (as former) and limited medical pensions but not all benefits that are enjoyed by four-star officers in the [[Pakistani military]]. ==Aftermath of Agosta submarine scandal== ===Later revelation and subsequent knowledge=== After the nationwide [[Pakistani general election, 2008|general elections]] held in 2008, which saw the [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] (PPP) forming the [[Gillani ministry|government]] and [[Asif Ali Zardari|Asif Zardari]] [[Pakistani presidential election, 2008|elected]] as [[President of Pakistan|President]], the knowledge on the Agosta submarines scandal became to emerge again, which brought several [[Pakistan Peoples Party|PPP politicians]] being involved in the scandal in public notice. Despite many investigative journalism reports and media airing the information gained on the Agosta submarines scandal, Haq remained silent and refused to appear on the [[Media of Pakistan|news media]]. Role of Adm. [[Saeed Mohammad Khan|SM Khan]] and others were also implicated, including the role of Aamir Lodhi, an [[arms dealer]] based in France who is also brother of Dr. [[Maleeha Lodhi]], currently serving as [[Permanent Representative of Pakistan to the United Nations|Permanent Representative of Pakistan]] to the [[United Nations]].{{cite news|last1=Special Report|title=Musharraf Fires US Spy Agency for Pushing Amir Lodhi's Arrest:Maleeha's Fugitive Brother Allowed to Sneak Away from Embassy in Washington|url=http://antisystemic.org/satribune/www.satribune.com/archives/nov9_15_03/P1_maleeha.htm|accessdate=8 September 2017|work=antisystemic.org|agency=South Asian Tribune|publisher=South Asian Tribune, 2003|date=5 November 2003}} Though, Adm. [[Saeed Mohammad Khan|SM Khan]] denied his role in such deals as the latter wanted to purchase the [[Upholder/Victoria-class submarine]]s in 1994. In 2010, [[Commodore (rank)|Cdre]] Shahid Ashraf, the [[Director-General|DG]] [[Naval Intelligence|NI]] under Admiral Haq, revealed on the [[Dawn News]] that the submarine deal, for which Admiral Mansurul Haq pleaded guilty, was signed before he took charge as Chief of Naval Staff.{{cite news|last1=staff writer|first1=editorial|title=DG Naval Intelligence ready to spill the beans|url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/archive/print/610048-dg-naval-intelligence-ready-to-spill-the-beans|accessdate=8 September 2017|work=www.thenews.com.pk|agency=The News International|publisher=The News International|date=10 November 2010|language=en}} Shahid Ashraf further claimed that Admiral Haq was not part of the selection team which recommended [[Agosta class submarine|Agosta 90B]] for purchase from France. The selection was made during Admiral [[Saeed Mohammad Khan]]. The selection committee included various Admirals including those who subsequently held senior positions after Admiral Haq was removed from his position. However, Shahid Ashraf did not put forward any evidence that proved Haq's innocence.{{YouTube|sL-TbIpotLs}} In June 2010, [[French police|French investigators]] raided the house of Amir Lodhi, and handed over the important documents relating the defence deals to the [[National Accountability Bureau|NAB]]. The reports confiscated by the French investigators revealed to have found in regards involvement of former [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Asif Ali Zardari]] who had have received [[Euros|€]]33 million while Amir Lodhi's share was [[Euros|€]]2.9 million.[http://www.nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/Politics/15-Jan-2011/Zardari-pocketed-millions-in-French-subs-deal-report "Zardari 'pocketed millions' in French subs deal: report"] ''Nation'', 15 January 2011 About the case study and trial of the Haq, former [[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|chief of naval staff]], [[Admiral|Adm.]] [[Abdul Aziz Mirza]] reportedly quoted in the [[Pakistani media|news media]] that "former Naval Chief Mansurul haq was not convicted of Agosta kickbacks but for the bribes he had pocketed in other defence deals."{{rp|contents}}{{cite book|last1=Sehri|first1=Inam|title=Judges and Generals in Pakistan|date=2013|publisher=Grosvenor House Publishing|isbn=9781781482346|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ZgRnAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT411&dq=mansurul+haq+aziz+mirza#v=onepage&q=mansurul%20haq%20aziz%20mirza&f=false|language=en}} ==See also== * [[Karachi Affair|Agosta submarine scandal]] * [[Corruption charges against Benazir Bhutto and Asif Ali Zardari]] * [[Corruption in Pakistan]] * [[Scandals|Military scandals]] * [[National Accountability Bureau]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{small|Prasad, Dr. Nitin (2016). {{Distinguish|Max Shreck|Max Schrock}} {{Infobox person | name = Max Schreck | image = Max Schreck 1922.jpg | image_size = | caption = Schreck in 1916 | birth_name = Friedrich Gustav Maximilian Schreck | birth_date = 6 September 1879 | birth_place = [[Berlin]], [[German Empire]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1936|2|20|1879|9|6|df=y}} | death_place = [[Munich]], [[Nazi Germany]] | occupation = [[Actor]] | years_active = 1920–1936 | spouse = {{marriage|[[Fanny Schreck|Fanny Normann]]|1910}} }}
'''Friedrich Gustav Maximilian Schreck'''<ref name=Eickhoff>[[#Eickhoff|Eickhoff, Stefan. 2007]]</ref> (6 September 1879 – 20 February 1936)<ref name=Brill/><ref name=Walk>[[#Walk|Walk, Ines. 2006]].</ref><ref>All reliable sources agree as to Schreck's actual date of birth and date of death.([[#Brill|Brill, Olaf. 2004]], [[#Walk|Walk, Ines. 2006]]) However, at least until 9 March 2009 the [[Internet Movie Database]] had incorrect and self-contradictory details. ([https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0775180/ IMDB bio]: "Date of Birth: 6 September 1879," ... "born on June 11, 1879" ... "Date of Death 26 November 1936," ... "death from a heart attack on February 19, 1936")</ref> was a German actor, best known for his lead role as the [[vampire]] [[Count Orlok]] in the film ''[[Nosferatu]]'' (1922).
==Biography== ===Early life=== Max Schreck was born in [[Friedenau|Berlin-Friedenau]], on 6 September 1879. Six years later, his father bought a house in the independent rural community of Friedenau, then part of the district of Teltow.
His father did not approve of Schreck's ever-growing enthusiasm for theater. Schreck's mother provided the boy with money, which he secretly used for acting lessons, although only after the death of his father did he attend drama school. After graduating, he travelled briefly across the country with poet and dramatist [[Demetrius Schrutz]].
Schreck had engagements in [[Mulhouse]], [[Międzyrzec Podlaski|Meseritz]], [[Speyer]], [[Rudolstadt]], [[Erfurt]] and [[Weissenfels]], and his first extended stay at the Gera Theater. Greater engagements followed, especially in Frankfurt am Main. From there he went to [[Berlin]] for [[Max Reinhardt (theatre director)|Max Reinhardt]] and the Munich Chamber Games for [[Otto Falckenberg]]. From then on he began to work in films.
Schreck received his training at the Berliner Staatstheater (State Theatre of [[Berlin]]), completing it in 1902.<ref name=Walk/> He made his stage début in [[Międzyrzec Podlaski|Meseritz]] and [[Speyer]], and then toured Germany for two years, appearing at theatres in [[Zittau]], [[Erfurt]], [[Bremen (city)|Bremen]],<ref name=Walk/> [[Lucerne]],<ref name=Walk/> [[Gera]],<ref name=Walk/> and [[Frankfurt am Main]].<ref name=Walk/> Schreck then joined [[Max Reinhardt (theatre director)|Max Reinhardt]]'s company of performers in Berlin.<ref name=missing>[http://www.missinglinkclassichorror.co.uk/max.htm Enigmatic Max: The career of Max Schreck]. Retrieved 26 December 2008</ref> Many members of Reinhardt's troupe went on to make significant contributions to the German film industry.<ref name=missing/>
===Career=== [[File:Schreck.jpg|thumb|right|Max Schreck in ''[[Nosferatu]]'' (1922)]] For three years between 1919 and 1922, Schreck appeared at the [[Munich Kammerspiele]],<ref name=missing/> including a role in the [[expressionism|expressionist]] production of [[Bertolt Brecht]]'s début, {{lang|de|Trommeln in der Nacht}} (''[[Drums in the Night]]'') (in which he played the "freakshow landlord" Glubb).<ref>[[#Brecht|Brecht, Willett and Manheim (1970, ix)]]</ref> During this time he also worked on his first film ''[[The Mayor of Zalamea (1920 film)|The Mayor of Zalamea]]'', adapted from a six-act play, for Decla Bioscop.<ref name=missing/> In 1921, he was hired by [[Prana Film]] for its first and only production, ''[[Nosferatu]]''. The company declared itself [[bankrupt]] after the film was released to avoid paying [[copyright infringement]] costs to ''[[Dracula]]'' author [[Bram Stoker]]'s widow, [[Florence Balcombe|Florence Stoker]].<ref name=missing/> Schreck portrayed [[Count Orlok]], a character analogous to [[Count Dracula]].<ref name=missing/>
In 1923, while still in Munich, Schreck appeared in a 16-minute (one-reeler) [[slapstick]], "surreal comedy" written by [[Bertolt Brecht]] with cabaret and stage actors [[Karl Valentin]], Liesl Karlstadt, [[Erwin Faber]], and Blandine Ebinger, entitled {{lang|de|Mysterien eines Friseursalons}} (''[[Mysteries of a Barbershop]]''), directed by Erich Engel.<ref>McDowell, W. Stuart. "A Brecht-Valentin Production: ''Mysteries of a Barbershop''", ''Performing Arts Journal'', Vol. 1, No. 3 (Winter, 1977), pp. 2-14; and "Acting Brecht: The Munich Years," by W. Stuart McDowell, in ''The Brecht Sourcebook'', Carol Martin, Henry Bial, editors (Routledge, 2000) p. 71 - 83.</ref> Also in 1923, Schreck appeared as a blind man in the film {{lang|de|[[Die Straße]]}} (''The Street'').<ref name=Brill>[[#Brill|Brill, Olaf. 2004]]</ref><ref name=missing/>
Schreck's second collaboration with ''Nosferatu'' director [[F. W. Murnau]] was the 1924 comedy {{lang|de|Die Finanzen des Grossherzogs}} (''[[The Grand Duke's Finances]]'').<ref name=missing/> Even Murnau did not hesitate to declare his contempt for the picture.<ref name=missing/> In 1926, Schreck returned to the Kammerspiele in Munich and continued to act in films surviving the advent of sound until his death in 1936 of [[heart failure]].<ref name="Gra2"/>
===Personal life=== [[File:Max schreck little girl.jpg|right|thumb|Schreck in ''[[Die Straße]]'' (1923)]] Schreck was married to actress [[Fanny Normann]],<ref name=missing/> who appeared in a few films, often credited as Fanny Schreck.
One of Schreck's contemporaries recalled that he was a loner with an unusual sense of humor and skill in playing grotesque characters. He also reported that he lived in "a remote and incorporeal world" and that he often spent time walking through forests.<ref name="Gra2">[[#Graham|Graham 2008]] [https://www.reuters.com/article/oddlyEnoughNews/idUSL0983779720080509?pageNumber=2&virtualBrandChannel=0 Page 2]. Retrieved 2008-12-26</ref>
===Death=== On 19 February 1936, Schreck had just played The Grand Inquisitor in the play {{lang|fr|[[Don Carlos]]}}, standing in for [[Will Dohm]]. That evening he felt unwell and the doctor sent him to the hospital where he died early the next morning of a heart attack.<ref name=obituary>[[#Brill|Brill 2004]], Peter Trumm: obituary in {{lang|de|Münchner Neueste Nachrichten}} vol. 89, no. 52, on 21 February 1936. {{lang|de|"am Donnerstag früh um einhalb neun Uhr im Schwabinger Krankenhaus gestorben"}} (ie. 08:30 in the morning of February 20, 1936)</ref> His [[obituary]] especially praised his role as [[The Miser]] in [[Molière]]'s comedy play.<ref name=obituary/> He was buried on 14 March 1936 at Wilmersdorfer Waldfriedhof Stahnsdorf in [[Brandenburg]].<ref name=Brill/>
==Cultural references== <!-- Per [[Wikipedia:Trivia sections]], only include items, in prose, with reliable third-party, non-wikipedia cites that source "the effect of the topic on popular culture." -->The person and performance of Max Schreck in ''[[Nosferatu]]'' was fictionalized by actor [[Willem Dafoe]] in [[E. Elias Merhige]]'s ''[[Shadow of the Vampire]]''.<ref name="Gra2"/> In a [[secret history]], ''Shadow'' posits that Schreck was a real [[vampire]].<ref name=NYT>{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/12/29/movies/film-review-son-of-nosferatu-with-a-real-life-monster.html|title=FILM REVIEW; Son of 'Nosferatu,' With a Real-Life Monster|author=Scott, A. O.|authorlink=A. O. Scott|date=December 29, 2000}}</ref>
Dafoe was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his portrayal of Schreck.<ref name="Nugent">{{cite web |first=Phil |last=Nugent |date=2008-05-13 |url=http://www.nerve.com/CS/blogs/screengrab/archive/2008/05/13/digging-up-max-shreck-the-screen-s-original-dracula.aspx |title=Digging Up Max Shreck, the Screen's Original Dracula |quote=The 2000 film ''Shadow of the Vampire'', starring John Malkovich as Murnau, was a darkly comic fantasy in which it was revealed that "Shreck" was an actual vampire (played by Willem Dafoe) that the director had brought in to lend his authenticity to the role. It was rooted in a film-scholar in-joke that went back decades. |accessdate=2009-05-21}}</ref>
Scriptwriter [[Daniel Waters (screenwriter)|Daniel Waters]] created the character Max Shreck<!-- spelt without the "c" --> (portrayed by [[Christopher Walken]]) for the [[Tim Burton]] film ''[[Batman Returns]]'' and compared him to the character Max Schreck played in ''Nosferatu''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.batmanytb.com/movies/batmanreturns/bios/villians.php |title=Batman YTB |quote=The script gave the writer (Daniel Waters) license to create his own villain in the form of Christopher Walken's nefarious Max Shreck, named after Max Schreck, the star of F.W. Murnau's NOSFERATU (1922). |accessdate=2009-05-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090129211942/http://www.batmanytb.com/movies/batmanreturns/bios/villians.php |archivedate=2009-01-29 |df= }}</ref> [[Variety magazine|''Variety'']] claimed the name was an in-joke.<ref name="Variety">{{cite web |first=Todd |last=McCarthy |date=1992-05-15 |publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' |url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117901465.html?categoryid=31&cs=1&p=0 |title=Batman Returns Review |quote=Max Shreck, a character named, as an in-joke, after the German actor who starred as the screen's first Dracula in F.W. Murnau's 1922 "Nosferatu." |accessdate=2009-05-21}}</ref>

[[File:Posmrtný portrét K. Horvath-Stansithovej, rod. Kissovej.jpeg|thumb|Mourning portrait of K. Horvath-Stansith, née Kiss, artist unknown, 1680s]] [[File:A Child of the Honigh Family on its Deathbed.jpg|thumb|''A Child of the Honigh Family on its Deathbed'', by an unknown painter, 1675-1700]] A '''mourning portrait''' or '''deathbed portrait''' is a portrait of a person who has recently died, usually shown on their deathbed, or [[lying in repose]], displayed for mourners. Though it seems like a morbid subject now, these were not rare in European homes of well-to-do people as a way of remembering and honoring the dead. Generally the name of the painter is unknown. Generally people were laid out in their best clothes with some sort of special headdress, and some sort of token in their hands. Today these portraits give insights into old funeral customs, but also various types of information regarding folk costumes. In the 19th century [[post-mortem photography]] continued the tradition.
Recent research on deathbed portraits, which can be found also in prints and photographs up to today, shows that they became popular after the [[Protestant Reformation]] but were never treasured as family heirlooms in the same way as other artworks and thus relatively few early examples such as this one have survived. As a continuous art form, laying out traditions did not go away and photography has continued to preserve the deathbed portrait, though such photos were meant for mourners and did not find their way into photo albums.
In the Netherlands, complicated wreaths of greens were placed around the heads of unmarried people, who were mostly children.<ref name=Pelen>[http://www.benhartman.nl/begrafenisrituelen/afleggen/versieren-pelen-van-het-lijk/ Afleggen en versieren van het lijk] ''Laying out and "palling" of the body'' on Dutch website</ref> In Dutch such a wreath is called a "hoedje" (little hat) and this is part of the general body decoration called "pelen".<ref>''Naar het lijk: het Nederlandse doodsportret 1500-heden'', catalog of [[Teylers Museum]] exhibition by Bert Sliggers, Walburg Pers, Zutphen, 1998 {{ISBN|9789057300424}}</ref> The word "pelen" is related to the English word "pall", as in "pallbearer", which in funeral contexts refers to the cloth (sometimes a flag) over the body or casket.
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:Deathbed portrait of Toropets merchant woman by anonim (19 c., Egorievsk).jpg|''Deathbed portrait of Toropets'', by anonymous 19th-century Russian painter File:Porträtt, Christian IV, okänd konstnär, Danmark ca 1648 - Skoklosters slott - 59332.tif|''Deathbed portrait of Christian IV'', [[King of Denmark]], by [[Berent Hilwaetz]], 1650 File:Schilderij, Prins Willem I - Zaltbommel - 20219641 - RCE.jpg|''Deathbed portrait of [[William the Silent]]'', by [[Christiaen Jansz van Bieselingen]], 1584 File:Jan Jansz. de Stomme - Kinderlijkje Groninger Museum.jpg|''Portrait of a dead child wearing a mourning wreath around its head'', by [[Jan Jansz. de Stomme]], 1654 </gallery>
An example of this type of portrait is the ''Mourning portrait of K. Horvath-Stansith, née Kiss'', an 1680s painting by an anonymous Baroque artist in the [[Slovak National Gallery]].<ref name=museum>[http://www.webumenia.sk/dielo/SVK:SNG.O_4842 collection record] on museum website</ref>
This painting shows a postmortem portrait of a woman from the Horvath-Stansith family, K. Horvath-Stansith. She appears to be lying on a bed, but her body has been specially prepared and she is lying not on a bed, but a prepared [[catafalque]] laid with a [[Kilim]] carpet and special red [[damask]] cushion. Her fingers have already discoloured and thread is wrapped around her thumbs. Theoretically, the location is her local church and this is how she looked during the funeral service. She is wearing the costume of the former Hungarian region of [[Levoča]] and the closefitting cap she has on is probably not the headgear she wore when she was alive. <gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:Unknown painter - Middle Class Woman of Lõcse - WGA23848.jpg|''Unknown Woman of Levoča'', 1641, by unknown painter, with similar bodice to K. Horvath-Stansith File:Fragments - Google Art Project.jpg|Red damask fragment from the same time period </gallery>

Japanese | budget = | gross = }} '''''Murder Collection V.1''''' is a 2009 American horror [[anthology film]] written and directed by [[Fred Vogel]], and co-written by Don Moore, Shelby Vogel and Jerami Cruise.{{cite book|author = Steve Jones|title = Torture Porn: Popular Horror after Saw|url = http://www.palgrave.com/us/book/9780230319417|accessdate = 25 February 2016|year = 2013|publisher = [[Palgrave Macmillan]]|isbn = 9781137317124|page = 174}}{{cite book|author = Alexandra Heller-Nicholas|title = Found Footage Horror Films: Fear and the Appearance of Reality|url = http://www.mcfarlandbooks.com/book-2.php?id=978-0-7864-7077-8|accessdate = 25 February 2016|year = 2014|publisher = [[McFarland & Company]]|isbn = 9780786470778|page = 194}} == Plot == The film's opening explains that in 1994 a [[web series]] called ''Murder'', which broadcast footage of actual deaths and acts of violence, appeared. After being active for four months, ''Murder'' was shut down by the authorities and had all of its content confiscated, though the website's host, a man known only as Balan, evaded capture. Now, years later, Balan has reemerged to share more clips that he has unearthed, while also offering commentary on people's obsession with death, the effect it has on them, and how accessible [[new media]] has made it. The series of videos is kicked off by Balan querying, "I ask you all... Why are you watching? Are you trying to find reality? Do you feel the need to be shocked? To witness something that human eyes shouldn't see? Murder is reality. Death comes when you least expect it. With what you are about to observe, you may question your own integrity. You will ask, could this happen to me? My answer to you is... Yes it can." * '''Bludgeoning:''' A drunk Russian man accidentally beats his teenage son to death in front of the son's [[webcam]]. * '''The Heist:''' A restaurant's security system records a robbery committed by four gunmen, who shoot a cashier in the head and a fleeing customer in the back. * '''The Cheat:''' In front of a stationary camera a man, Greg reminisces about how he met his wife, and about all of the good times that they shared, while a monitor in the background shows his wife having sex with someone else. The man leaves the room, and the monitor shows him barging in on his wife and her lover, hacking the former to death with an ax before cutting out her heart, which the wife had once said would always belong to him. * '''S&G:''' A parking lot security camera catches two people attacking a couple, beating the man with a baseball bat, and abducting the woman. * '''Broadway Rob:''' The distorted home movie of a pedophile, Broadway Rob who forces two gagged boys, Shawn and Ben clad in only their socks and underwear to dance with him. Shawn tackles Rob, fatally strangling and stabbing him. Shawn and Ben flee, leaving Rob's dead body behind. * '''Execution:''' A muffled black and white [[camcorder]] video of a hooded and masked group (possibly a [[cult]] or a gang) executing a man via decapitation in front of a woman, whom they taunt with the severed head before shooting her. * '''ATM:''' A man is mugged and killed at an [[Automated teller machine|ATM]]. * '''Autopsy:''' Japanese autopsy footage of a woman who was shot in the mouth, with the bullet exiting the top of her skull. The coroner eventually kicks the cameraman out due to his unprofessional antics and inattentiveness. * '''Bullied:''' A trio of drunks use a camcorder to record themselves taking a man out into the woods under the pretense of initiating him into their group. The three bully and humiliate the man and, during a scuffle, one of them accidentally knocks him onto the knife another was holding. The trio panic and bicker, and the camera is dropped when a fight breaks out over whether they should go for help. * '''Homecoming:''' A building security camera records two figures [[Garrote|garroting]] a man. * '''Ransom:''' A deteriorated series of [[ransom]] videos depict three men brutalizing a [[Senate|senator's]] daughter, who eventually dies due to the severity of her injuries. After the last clip, Balan delivers the closing statement, "You realize now it's everywhere. Death casts a shadow on all our faces. The new media shines light on dank crevasses, revealing moral decay and broken experiences that are better left beyond the pale. Goosebumps explode on my skin with every clip we watch. I feel it now more than ever. How do you feel?" == Cast == * Opening Credits: ** Mary Shore as The Victim * Bludgeoning: ** Daniel V. Klein as Father ** Damien A. Maruscak as Son * The Heist: ** Sonny L. Shannon as The Manager ** Matthew Plutko as The Cook ** Shelby Lyn Vogel as The Tender ** Sean L. Joyce as The Sprinter ** Rebecca Tronzo as Topaz ** Eric Schwartzbauer as Leon ** Aziza as Madam Green ** Don Moore as G.A. Arnold as The Doctor * Bullied: ** Adrian Alexander D'Amico as Cope ** Dave Dalessandro as Jake ** Michael Witherel as Castle ** Jay Mattingly as Gromer * Homecoming: ** Stephen Vogel as Eddie the Rat ** Kai Peter as Zack ** Jason Spence as Hudson * Ransom: ** Harvey Daniels as Jovan ** [[Ruckus (wrestler)|Claude Marrow]] as Sidel ** Clint Brown as Deron ** Lacey Fleming as Ginnifer Mitchell == Reception == Ryan Doom of [[JoBlo.com|Arrow in the Head]] gave ''Murder Collection V.1'' a 2/4 and wrote, "In the end, I think it's an interesting exercise, but I don't know if it makes it a good movie. This isn't the type of film that I suspect most viewers would revisit often, if at all. Instead, it's just an experiment that people will dig or not, depending on how much violence and gore they can stomach without a story for context. While it captivated me at times with certain segments, others seemed unnecessary or overdone. But maybe that's just me".{{cite web|url = http://www.joblo.com/horror-movies/dvd-reviews/murder-collection-v1|title = ''Murder Collection V.1''|last = Doom|first = Ryan|publisher = Arrow in the {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Perry County Jane Doe | image = File:Perry Jane Doe.jpg | image_size = | alt = Digital image (right) created from CT scan of skull to depict an estimation of the victim in life | caption = Latest rendering of Perry County Jane Doe | birth_name = | birth_date = 1941 - 1963 (aged 15 - 38) (approximate) | birth_place = | death_date = 1978 - 1979 | death_place = | disappeared_status = {{Unidentified for|1979|06|20}} | death_cause = Undetermined, considered suspicious | body_discovered = June 20, 1979
Watts Township, Perry County, Pennsylvania, United States | other_names = | known_for = | height = {{height|ft=5|in=2|abbr=mos}}(minimum)
{{height|ft=5|in=8|abbr=mos}} (maximum) | weight = {{convert|105|lb|kg}} (minimum)
{{convert|125|lb|kg}}(maximum) }} '''Perry County Jane Doe''', also nicknamed as "'''Girl with the Turquoise Jewelry'''" is an unidentified woman whose body was found on June 20, 1979, in [[Watts Township, Perry County, Pennsylvania]], near the [[Juniata River]]. The cause of her death is not known, but it was considered to be suspicious by the authorities.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 5166|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/5166|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=24 August 2014|date=5 May 2009}} Her name is still not known, despite efforts to identify her.{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Jeffery A.|title=State police release sketch of woman whose body was found in 1979 in Perry County|url=http://www.pennlive.com/midstate/index.ssf/2013/05/state_police_release_sketch_of.html|accessdate=27 November 2014|work=The Patriot News|date=30 May 2013}}{{cite web|title=Jane Doe 1979|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMC/1192091/1#poster|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing and Exploited Children]]|accessdate=24 August 2014}}{{cite web|title=Case File 11UFPA|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/11ufpa.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=24 August 2014}} She is the only [[unidentified decedent]] in the county. ==Description== The badly decomposed remains were found by a "stone mason" alongside a river, near a highway in [[Perry County, Pennsylvania]], near [[Watts Township, Perry County, Pennsylvania|Watts Township]]. The remains were mostly skeletonized and the estimated time of death was months before, perhaps as early as Autumn of 1978. The decedent is believed to have been between 15 and 30 years old, although she may have been as old as 38. She was [[White American|white]], had straight, shoulder-length [[blond]] or light [[brown hair]] and was between 5 feet 2 inches and 5 feet 9 inches tall. She had received [[dentistry|dental care]] during her life, as a back tooth had been removed four or five years prior to her death. She also had [[dental filling|teeth fillings]]. One tooth, which was a [[molar (tooth)|molar]], had not yet erupted. Her teeth showed no evidence of crowding. Despite that her teeth appeared to have had some dental work, it is not known if she had ever had braces.{{cite web|title=SUSPICIOUS DEATH/UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE - WATTS TOWNSHIP, PERRY COUNTY, PENNSYLVANIA|url=https://www.crimewatchpa.com/crimestoppers/316/cases/suspicious-deathunidentified-female-watts-township-perry-county-pennsylvania|website=crimewatchpa.com|publisher=Pennsylvania Crime Stoppers|accessdate=24 August 2014|year=2014}} Prior to her death, she had suffered a fractured [[rib]], which had healed. Just before her death, she may have returned to Pennsylvania after having spent several months in the southwestern United States.{{cite web|title=New lead on Jane Doe found in Pennsylvania|url=https://www.facebook.com/notes/help-id-me/new-lead-on-jane-doe-found-in-pennsylvania/991211054240135?notif_t=notify_me|publisher=National Center for Missing & Exploited Children|accessdate=22 January 2015|date=22 January 2015}} Recent analysis of the decedent's bones indicated that she had spent a long time living in the [[Midwest]] or in Canada, near the [[Great Lakes]], when she was an adolescent. ==Belongings== [[File:Perry Jewelry.jpg|300px|thumb|Jewelry worn by Perry County Jane Doe.]] Perry County Jane Doe wore several pieces of [[jewelry]]. She was wearing two [[sterling silver]] rings with [[turquoise]] stones, one of which also contained [[onyx]] pieces that are believed to have originated in the Southwest, possibly having been made by [[Navajo people|Navajo]] or [[Zuni people|Zuni]] Indians inhabiting that area.{{cite news|title=FBI's Nameless Victims Of Violent Crime|url=http://www.ksbw.com/news/16416160#!bJhwpa|accessdate=24 August 2014|agency=KSBW News|publisher=ABC|date=5 September 2012}} She also had a chain bracelet on her right arm and a turquoise necklace and earrings. The jewelry led authorities to believe the victim had ties to [[Arizona]], [[New Mexico]] or a similar region.{{cite news|title=Does Pennsylvania suspicious death investigation have an Arizona link?|url=http://www.abc15.com/news/state/does-pennsylvania-suspicious-death-investigation-have-an-arizona-link|accessdate=26 February 2016|work=ABC 15 Arizona|publisher=Scripps Media, Inc|date=4 May 2013|location=Phoenix, Arizona}} She wore a tan jacket, white boots with silver buckles, green and white socks, and blue slacks.{{cite web|title=JANE DOE Newport, Watts Township, Perry County, Pennsylvania|url=https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/vicap/unidentified-persons/@@wanted-group-scroll-view?selected-uid=cb6907bf45a260ecb8d8252ab909d08f|website=fbi.gov|publisher=[[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]|accessdate=24 August 2014}} The slacks were described as having been made from knitted wool which contained strands of red thread. She was wearing two [[Top (clothing)|tops]], which consisted of a white shirt and a blue [[Sleeveless shirt|tank top]]. ==Investigation== The victim had been buried shortly after her discovery, but was exhumed in 2008, following the reopening of her case. Her [[DNA profiling|DNA]] and dental records were recorded and are on file. Because of the condition of her remains, no fingerprints and no cause of death could be confirmed. An initial examination of her teeth indicated that she had had three teeth extracted, but this was later disproved. Despite the fact that these characteristics have been entered into national databases, there have been no matches with missing persons. About sixty possible identities for her have been ruled out.{{cite news|last1=Lanyon|first1=Ali|title=Midstate Mysteries: The girl with the turquoise jewelry|url=http://www.abc27.com/story/22040531/midstate-mysteries-the-girl-with-the-turquoise-jewelry|accessdate=24 August 2014|agency=WHTM News|publisher=ABC|date=22 April 2013}} Her face was [[forensic facial reconstruction|reconstructed]] twice by professionals. A sketch by Barbara Martin-Bailey was drawn in 2009, and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children created a three-dimensional rendering by digitally adding layers of muscles and skin to a [[CT scan]] of her skull, which was released in 2013. A revised image was later released in 2018. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Unidentified murder victims}} *{{NCMEC|1192091|Perry County Jane Doe}} *{{NamUs|5166|Perry County Jane Doe}} *{{Doe Network|11ufpa.html}} {{Unidentified decedent}} [[Category:1978 deaths]] [[Category:1978 in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:1979 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century births]] [[Category:Murdered American children]] [[Category:Unidentified American children]] [[Category:Unidentified murder victims in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Unsolved murders in the United States]] [[Category:People murdered in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:People who were forensically reconstructed]] [[Category:Violence against women in the United States]] [[Category:Female murder victims]]
